title.value: One-4-All: Neural Potential Fields for Embodied Navigation
title.quote: One-4-All: Neural Potential Fields for Embodied Navigation

extractions.description: The paper introduces One-4-All (O4A), a method for end-to-end, graph-free, image-goal navigation in robotics. The system leverages self-supervised manifold learning to continuously minimize a neural potential function over image embeddings for real-world navigation tasks.

type.justification: The paper presents a new methodology and evaluates its performance on both simulated and real-world tasks, making it an empirical study.
type.quote: We show that O4A can reach long-range goals in 8 simulated Gibson indoor environments and that resulting embeddings are topologically similar to ground truth maps, even if no pose is observed. We further demonstrate successful real-world navigation using a Jackal UGV platform.

name.justification: The paper addresses the task of navigation in robotics, proposing a new method for robot navigation using image-goals.
name.quote: A fundamental task in robotics is to navigate between two locations.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on embodied navigation, where robots navigate using high-dimensional image data.
name.quote: In particular, real-world navigation can require long-horizon planning using high-dimensional RGB images, which poses a substantial challenge for end-to-end learning-based approaches.

name.justification: The method relies on self-supervised learning to train the models for navigation.
name.quote: O4A is trained offline using non-expert exploration sequences of RGB data and controls. We first rely on self-supervised learning to identify neighboring RGB observations.

name.justification: The training procedure includes a manifold learning objective for the geodesic regressor to predict shortest path lengths.
name.quote: we compute a graph to derive a manifold learning objective for our planning module, which we dub the geodesic regressor.

name.justification: One-4-All (O4A) is the core model proposed in the paper for navigation tasks.
name.quote: In this work, we present One-4-All (O4A), a method leveraging self-supervised and manifold learning to obtain a graph-free, end-to-end navigation pipeline in which the goal is specified as an image.

is_contributed.justification: The model is novel and is introduced in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we present One-4-All (O4A), a method leveraging self-supervised and manifold learning to obtain a graph-free, end-to-end navigation pipeline in which the goal is specified as an image.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed and evaluated in both simulated and real-world environments.
is_executed.quote: We show that O4A can reach long-range goals in 8 simulated Gibson indoor environments and that resulting embeddings are topologically similar to ground truth maps, even if no pose is observed. We further demonstrate successful real-world navigation using a Jackal UGV platform.

is_compared.justification: O4A has been compared with various other models to evaluate its performance in different settings.
is_compared.quote: To assess the navigation performance of our method, we compare against the following baselines: Random Agent, Goal Conditioned Behavioral Cloning (GC-BC), SPTM, ViNG.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary model of the paper and there is no referenced paper for this model.

name.justification: The Gibson Environment dataset is used in the simulated experiments.
name.quote: We perform our experiments using the Habitat simulator with the Gibson dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Xia, F., R. Zamir, Z. He, A. Sax, J. Malik, and S. Savarese. Gibson Env: Real-World Perception for Embodied Agents. In Proc. IEEE CVPR, pp. 9068-9079, 2018.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced in the paper and used for simulated navigation tasks.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We perform our experiments using the Habitat simulator with the Gibson dataset [39].

name.justification: The Habitat simulator was used for the simulation experiments in the paper.
name.quote: We perform our experiments using the Habitat simulator with the Gibson dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Savva, M., et al. Habitat: A Platform for Embodied AI Research. In Proc. ICCV, 2019.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Habitat simulator is referenced in the paper and used for simulated navigation experiments.
